`Aliases
ŃAction, Transaction
Ńfunctor (function object)
`Intent
ŃEncapsulate a request as an object, thereby letting you 
parameterize clients with different requests, queue or 
log requests, and support undoable operations.
`Motivation
Ńᚥૂ䈭≸ᢝ㺂䗽ぁሷ㻻䎭ᶛ
Ńframework ᔶθ
command ᔶ
Ń䇮䙐䗽ཐ〃䙊ᖺ䈹⭞ੂжѠ䈭≸Ⱦ ——䈭≸Ⲻ䠃⭞

`Applicability φUse the Command pattern when : 
Ńparameterize objects by an action to perform θԙᴵഔ
䈹
Ńspecify, queue, and execute requests at different 
times
Ńsupport undo
Ńsupport logging changes so that they can be reapplied 
in case of a system crash
Ństructure a system around high-level operations built 
on primitives operations —— transactions

`Struct
`Participants
ŃClient, Command ȽConcreteCommand ȽInvoker ȽReceiver
`Collaborations

`Evaluation
ŃCommand decouples the object that invokes the operation 
from the one that knows how to perform it. 
ŃCommands are first-class objects. They can be manipulated 
and extended like any other object. 
ŃYou can assemble commands into a composite command. An 
example is MacroCommand.
ŃIt's easy to add new Commands, because you don't have to 
change existing classes. 
`Implementation
ŃHow intelligent should a command be?
ŃSupporting undo and redo
ŃAvoiding error accumulation in the undo process
ŃUsing C++ templates

`Related Patterns
ŃComposite ⁗ᕅਥ⭞ᶛᇔ⧦ command 㓺ਾ
ŃѰᇔ⧦undo/redo Ԍ㺂Ѱ⁗ᕅᶛ㇗⨼⣬ᘷθྸ
memento ⁗ᕅȾCommand ࡦhistory list θਥԛ⭞
prototype 㠠䓡
`Examples

`Aliases φCursor
`Intent
ŃProvide a way to access the elements of an 
aggregate object sequentially without exposing 
its underlying representation.
`Motivation
ŃAn aggregate object such as a list should give 
you a way to access its elements without 
exposing its internal structure.
ŃSeparating the traversal mechanism from the List 
object lets us define iterators for different 
traversal policies without enumerating them in 
the List interface.

`Applicability φUse the Iterator pattern when : 
Ńto access an aggregate object's contents without 
exposing its internal representation.
Ńto support multiple traversals of aggregate objects.
Ńto provide a uniform interface for traversing 
different aggregate structures (that is, to support 
polymorphic iteration).

`Struct
`Participants
ŃIterator ȽConcreteIterator ȽAggregate ȽConcreteAggregate

`Evaluation
ŃIt supports variations in the traversal of an aggregate
ŃIterators simplify the Aggregate interface
ŃMore than one traversal can be pending on an aggregate
`Implementation
Ńᇔ⧦ਥԛ䶔ᑮ⚫⍱
ŃWho controls the iteration? 
xexternal iterator versus internal iterator
ŃWho defines the traversal algorithm? 
xAggregate ᵢ䓡ᇐѿ㇍⌋ —— Cursor mode
xiterator ᇐѿ㇍⌋ —— iterator ྸ֋䇵䰤ᮦᦤ
ŃHow robust is the iterator?

`Implementation( 㔣)
ŃAdditional Iterator operations. 
xφ First, Next, IsDone, and CurrentItem
ŃUsing polymorphic iterators —— iterator 䍺Ⓠ䠀᭴
ŃIterators may have privileged access
ŃIterators for composites —— 䘸ਾӄinternal 
iterator ᡌ㘻cursor ᯯᕅⲺiterator
ŃNull iterators

`Related Patterns
ŃComposite φiterator ᑮ㻡⭞ӄ composite ⁗ᕅⲺགྷਾ㔉ᶺ
ŃPolymorphic iterators rely on factory methods to 
instantiate the appropriate Iterator subclass.
`Examples
ŃCOM enumerator φconnectable object Ƚ…
ŃADO/OLE DB
ŃC++ STL
x൞STLѣθiterator ᱥ䘔᧛algorithm ૂcontainer Ⲻẛặ

`Aliases φDependents, Publish-Subscribe
`Intent
ŃDefine a one-to-many dependency between objects so that 
when one object changes state, all its dependents are 
notified and updated automatically .
`Motivation
Ńж
㠪ᙝϋ
ŃThe key objects in this pattern are subject and observer 
xOne-to-many relationship
xA subject may have any number of dependent observers. 
xAll observers are notified whenever the subject undergoes a 
change in state.

`Applicability φUse the Observer pattern when : 
ŃWhen an abstraction has two aspects, one dependent 
on the other. Encapsulating these aspects in separate 
objects lets you vary and reuse them independently. 
ŃWhen a change to one object requires changing others, 
and you don't know how many objects need to be 
changed. 
ŃWhen an object should be able to notify other objects 
without making assumptions about who these objects 
are. In other words, you don't want these objects 
tightly coupled.

`Struct
`Participants
ŃSubject ȽConcreteSubject ȽObserver ȽConcreteObserver
`Collaborations

`Evaluation
ŃAbstract coupling between Subject and Observer
ŃSupport for broadcast communication
ŃUnexpected updates
`Implementation
ŃMapping subjects to their observers. 
ŃObserving more than one subject
ŃWho triggers the update? Client or subject ϋ
ŃMaking sure Subject state is self-consistent before 
notification
Ńsubject ੇobserver ᚥ
Ńޛ ChangeManager

`Aliases φPolicy
`Intent
ŃDefine a family of algorithms, encapsulate each one, 
and make them interchangeable. Strategy lets the 
algorithm vary independently from clients that use it.
`Motivation
Ńᴿӑ㇍⌋ሯӄḆӑ㊱ᱥᗻуਥቇⲺθռᱥу䘸ਾӄ⺢㕌䘑㊱
᯦Ⲻ㇍⌋
ᇔ⧦ᡌ㘻᭯਎⧦ᴿⲺ㇍⌋ᇔ⧦
Ńঋ⤢Ⲻ㊱ѣθ〦Ѱ strategy

`Applicability φUse the Strategy pattern 
when : 
Ńmany related classes differ only in their behavior. 
Ńyou need different variants of an algorithm. 
Ńan algorithm uses data that clients shouldn't know 
about. 
Ńa class defines many behaviors, and these appear 
as multiple conditional statements in its operations.

`Struct
`Participants
ŃStrategy ȽConcreteStrategy ȽContex t
`CollaborationsŃStrategy and Context interact to implement the chosen algorithm
ŃA context forwards requests from its clients to its strategy

`Evaluation
ŃFamilies of related algorithms
ŃAn alternative to subclassing
ŃStrategies eliminate conditional statements
ŃClients must be aware of different Strategies
ŃCommunication overhead between Strategy and 
Context
ŃIncreased number of objects
`Implementation
ŃDefining the Strategy and Context interfaces
ŃStrategies as template parameters
ŃMaking Strategy objects optional

`Related Patterns
Ńflyweight φ㘹㲇⭞ flyweight ⁗ᕅᶛᇔ⧦ strategy ሯ䊗
`Examples

`Intent
ŃRepresent an operation to be performed on the 
elements of an object structure. Visitor lets you define 
a new operation without changing the classes of the 
elements on which it operates.
`Motivation

`Applicability φUse the Visitor pattern when

`Struct

`Participants
ŃClient ȽVisitor ȽConcreteVisitor ȽObjectStructure ȽElement Ƚ
ConcreteElement
`Collaborations
Ńclient ᔰжѠ ConcreteVisitor θ❬੄䚃় ObjectStructure

`Evaluation
ŃVisitor makes adding new operations easy
ŃA visitor gathers related operations and separates unrelated ones
ŃAdding new ConcreteElement classes is hard. 
Ńуᱥ㊱ቸ⅗θ visitor ҕਥԛᇔ᯳
Ń⣬ᘷ㍥〥
Ńvisitor ㍖Ⲻ⣬ᘷθᡶԛ㾷ᢉ⹪ሷ㻻
`Implementation
Ńdouble-dispatch θAccept ᇔ⧦Ҽdouble dispatch
This is the key to the Visitor pattern: The operation that 
gets executed depends on both the type of Visitor and the 
type of Element it visits. 
ŃWho is responsible for traversing the object structure?
